Propositional logic 1

Defining the language

Erik Hoversten

Rutgers university: LRP, fall 2014

October 22, 2014

A formal logic is defined by its language

The key parts of any language are:

  • Vocabulary
    • Logical vocabulary
    • Non-logical vocabulary
  • Syntax
    • Rules for putting vocabulary together into propositions
  • Semantics
    • Rules for interpreting the meaning of propositions

Categorical logic

In categorical logic, our language was:

  • Vocabulary
    • Logical: Quantifiers and copula
    • Non-logical: Subject and predicate terms
  • Syntax
    • [Quantifier] + [Subject term] + [copula] + [Predicate term]
  • Semantics
    • Specification of each proposition's meaning in terms of set inclusion and exclusion

Propositional logic

Propositional logic is another formal logic with a slightly different language:

  • Vocabulary
    • Logical: 1-place connectives, 2-place connectives
    • Non-logical: Propositions
  • Syntax
    • [1-place connective] + [proposition]
    • [proposition] + [2-place connective] + [propostition]
  • Semantics
    • Meaning is specified in terms of truth conditions

Propositional logic

We define the formal logic by specifying completely each component of the language used to express the logic

Vocabulary

Logical

  • 1-place connective:
    • takes 1 proposition and makes a compound proposition
      • ~ (tilde) : not, it is not the case that
  • 2-place connective:
    • take 2 propositions an make a compound proposition
      • ∙ (dot) : and, in addition, both ... and __
      • ∨ (vee) : or, either ... or __
      • ⊃ (horseshoe) : if ... then __ , ... only if __, ... unless __
      • ≡ (triple bar) : ... is equivalent to __ , ... if and only if __
  • Parentheses: ( , )

Vocabulary

Non-logical

  • Atomic propositions:
    • John went to the store
    • Mary ate baked tofu
  • We abstract over the content of propositions by replacing them with propositional variables:
    • A, B, C, ...

Syntax

The sentences of propositional logic

  • [proposition]
    • A, B, C, ...
  • [1-place connective] + [proposition]
    • Negation: ~A
  • [proposition] + [2-place connective] + [proposition]
    • Conjunction: A ∙ B
    • Disjunction: C ∨ D
    • Conditional: E ⊃ F
    • Biconditional: G ≡ H

Formulas

A formula is any combination of bits from the vocabulary of the language.

  • WFFs
    • Not all possible formulas belong to the language of propositional logic. The good ones must follow the syntax on the previous slide.
    • Any syntactic unit that meets the specification above is a well-formed formula (WFF)
    • The WFFs compose the entire language of propositional logic
    • Propositional variables can stand for any WFF, either atomic or compound

Recursion

Compound propositions are also propositions, so we can use connectives to connect compound propositions as well as atomic ones.

  • The process of building bigger peices from smaller peices of the same type is known as recursion
  • We use parentheses to set off each compound proposition from the others in the WFF
  • Examples:
    • (A ∙ B) ⊃ (C ∨ D)
    • (~M ≡ Q) ∙ R

Languages with recursion are capable of expressing and infinite number of propositions.

Semantics

In propositional logic, we specify the meaning of WFFs in terms their truth conditions.

  • Truth conditions specify the way the world must be in order for the proposition to be true.
    • What a proposition means is the set of situations in which it is true.
  • Examples:
    • "Jack went to the store" is true just in case Jack went to the store.
    • "Felicity got a perm and Mike likes it" is true just in case both Felicity got a perm and Mike likes Felicity's perm
    • "Garth is at the party or he had a fight with Wayne" is true just in case either Garth is at the party or Garth had a fight with Wayne

Truth tables

To provide the meaning for a WFF, we outline all the different ways it can be true or false. The tool we use to do this is a truth table.

Step 1: Construct the columns

  1. Make a column for every distinct propositional variable in the WFF, and label the column with a distinct meta-variable (p, q, r, ...)
  2. Add a column for the complete WFF

Truth tables

Step 2: Calculate the number of rows

  • Make a row for every distinct combination of truth values the meta-variables can have
  • As a rule, if there are n propositional variables in the WFF, there will be 2n combinations of truth values
    • If the WFF includes an A and a B, there will be 22 = 4 rows in the table
    • If the WFF includes a C, a D, and an E, there will be 23 = 8 rows in the table

Truth tables

Step 3: Fill the columns

  • Divide the number of rows in half. In the first column, fill the first half of the rows with Ts, and the second half of the rows with Fs
  • Divide the rows in half again. In the second column, fill the first quarter of the rows with Ts, the second quarter with Fs, and continue on, alternating every quarter.
  • Continue this process until the column for your last propositional variable has alternating Ts and Fs all the way down.

Truth table for atomic propositions

  • Atomic propositions can only be either true or false, so their truth table is pretty boring.
    • Since there are two distinct ways an atomic proposition could turn out, two rows appear on the table.
    • We put a T to stand for true and an F to stand for false
p
T
F

Truth table for negation

~p

  • Negation switches the truth value of the contained proposition.
  • We call the contained proposition the prejacent
  • If the prejacent is true, then the negation is false, and if the prejacent is false, then the negation is true
p ~p
T F
F T

Truth table for conjunction

p ∙ q

  • We call each of the propositions in a conjunction a conjunct.
  • A conjunction is true just in case both of the propositions that make it up are true. Otherwise, it is false.
  • Since there are two conjuncts, the truth table has 4 rows.
p q p ∙ q
T T T
T F F
F T F
F F F

Truth table for disjunction

p ∨ q

  • We call each of the propositions in a disjunction a disjunct.
  • A disjunction is true just in case at least one of the propositions that make it up are true.
  • It is only false if both disjuncts are false.
p q p ∨ q
T T T
T F T
F T T
F F F

Truth table for conditionals

p ⊃ q

  • We call the first proposition in a conditional the antecedent, and the second proposition the consequent.
  • A conditional is true just in case either the antecedent is false, or the consequent is true.
  • It is false only when the antecedent is true, but the consequent is false
p q p ⊃ q
T T T
T F F
F T T
F F T

Truth table for biconditionals

p ≡ q

  • A biconditional is equivalent to a conjunction of conditionals
    • (p ⊃ q) ∙ (q ⊃ p)
  • A biconditional is true just in case the antecedent and the consequent have the same truth value.
p q p ≡ q
T T T
T F F
F T F
F F T

Propositional logic vs. English

The connectives of propositional logic are intended to translate certain words of English.

  • It's possible that the truth conditions that propositional logic assigns to the connective don't match our intuitions about how the associated English word is used.
  • In propositional logic, the truth conditions are all there is to the meaning of the connective.

Dot vs. "And"

The dot in a proposition such as A ∙ B is meant to translate the English word "and", but it doesn't mean the exact same thing.

  • Compare:
    1. Lisa and John got married and they had a baby.
    2. Lisa and John had a baby and they got married.
  • While (1) is nothing special, (2) might suggest that a shotgun played a role in the wedding.
  • In English, the order of conjuncts often suggests a temporal ordering.
  • But in propositional logic, all that matters is whether both conjuncts are true or not.
    • Since both (1) and (2) involve the same conjuncts, they will always have the same meaning in propositional logic.

Vee vs. "Or"

The vee in a proposition such as A ∨ B is meant to translate the English word "or", but it doesn't mean the exact same thing.

  • Consider:
    1. You can have soup with that or you can get salad.
    2. Either he leaves or I do!
  • If your waiter at a restaurant said (1) to you, you would probably get charged extra if you asked for both soup and salad.
  • In English, "or" often expresses exclusivity, in that one or the other disjuncts can be true, but not both.
  • But in propositional logic, disjunction is inclusive in that the disjunction is true so long as one, the other, or both disjuncts are true.

Horseshoe vs. "If, then"

The horseshoe in a proposition such as A ⊃ B is meant to translate the English words "if, then", but it doesn't mean the exact same thing.

  • Consider:
    1. If pigs fly, then frogs can sing opera.
    2. If Erik has brown hair, then class is really exciting today.
  • In English, "if, then" often suggests a causal relation holds between the antecedent and the consequent.
  • But in propositional logic, the conditional is only false if the antecedent is true, and the consequent is false.
    • Since (1) has a false antecedent, and (2) has a true consequent, both are true in propositional logic.

Truth functions

  • What the last slides are meant to show is that propositional logic only cares about truth values.
  • If you know the truth value of the propostitions contained in a compound proposition, then you don't need to know anything else about them.
  • All the connectives in propositional logic are truth functional.
  • This fact is what allows us to treat propositional logic as a formal logic. We don't need to know anything about the content of the propositions. As long as we know what form they take, we can determine all the possible truth values it could have.
